member.summary: The device accepted the command, but returned sense data, indicating an error.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_NO_SUCH_MODE_PAGE
member.summary: The device reported that the requested mode page (and type) is not present.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_NO_MEDIA
member.summary: There is no media in the device.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_INCOMPATIBLE
member.summary: The media is not compatible or of unknown physical format.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_UPSIDE_DOWN
member.summary: The media is inserted upside down.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_BECOMING_READY
member.summary: The drive reported that it is in the process of becoming ready. Please try the request again later.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_FORMAT_IN_PROGRESS
member.summary: The media is currently being formatted. Please wait for the format to complete before attempting to use the media.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_BUSY
member.summary: The drive reported that it is performing a long-running operation, such as finishing a write. The drive may be unusable for a long period of time.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_INVALID_MODE_PARAMETERS
member.summary: The drive reported that the combination of parameters provided in the mode page for a MODE SELECT command were not supported.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_WRITE_PROTECTED
member.summary: The drive reported that the media is write protected.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_NO_SUCH_FEATURE
member.summary: The feature page requested is not supported by the device.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_FEATURE_IS_NOT_CURRENT
member.summary: The feature page requested is supported, but is not marked as current.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_GET_CONFIGURATION_NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: The drive does not support the GET CONFIGURATION command.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_COMMAND_TIMEOUT
member.summary: The device failed to accept the command within the timeout period. This may be caused by the device having entered an inconsistent state, or the timeout value for the command may need to be increased.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_DVD_STRUCTURE_NOT_PRESENT
member.summary: The DVD structure is not present. This may be caused by incompatible drive/medium used.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_SPEED_MISMATCH
member.summary: The media's speed is incompatible with the device. This may be caused by using higher or lower speed media than the range of speeds supported by the device.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_LOCKED
member.summary: The device associated with this recorder during the last operation has been exclusively locked, causing this operation to failed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_CLIENT_NAME_IS_NOT_VALID
member.summary: The client name is not valid.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_MEDIA_NOT_FORMATTED
member.summary: The media is not formatted. Please format the media before attempting to use it.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_RECORDER_INVALID_RESPONSE_FROM_DEVICE
member.summary: The device reported unexpected or invalid data for a command.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_LOSS_OF_STREAMING
member.summary: The write failed because the drive did not receive data quickly enough to continue writing. Moving the source data to the local computer, reducing the write speed, or enabling a "buffer underrun free" setting may resolve this issue.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_UNEXPECTED_RESPONSE_FROM_DEVICE
member.summary: The write failed because the drive returned error information that could not be recovered from.

member.summary: There is no write operation currently in progress.

member.summary: There is no write operation currently in progress.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_ERASE_DISC_INFORMATION_TOO_SMALL
member.summary: The drive did not report sufficient data for a READ DISC INFORMATION command. The drive may not be supported, or the media may not be correct.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_ERASE_MODE_PAGE_2A_TOO_SMALL
member.summary: The drive did not report sufficient data for a MODE SENSE (page 0x2A) command. The drive may not be supported, or the media may not be correct.

member.summary: The drive reported that the media is not erasable.

member.summary: The drive failed the erase command.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_ERASE_TOOK_LONGER_THAN_ONE_HOUR
member.summary: The drive did not complete the erase in one hour. The drive may require a power cycle, media removal, or other manual intervention to resume proper operation.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_ERASE_UNEXPECTED_DRIVE_RESPONSE_DURING_ERASE
member.summary: The drive returned an unexpected error during the erase. The the media may be unusable, the erase may be complete, or the drive may still be in the process of erasing the disc.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.HRESULT.E_IMAPI_ERASE_DRIVE_FAILED_SPINUP_COMMAND
member.summary: The drive returned an error for a START UNIT (spinup) command. Manual intervention may be required.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus
member.summary:
Formal replacement for the Windows NTStatus definition. In ntstatus.h, it is a defined UINT value. For .NET, this class strongly types the value.
The 32-bit value is organized as follows:
Bit 0 - 1 2 3 4 - 15 16 - 31
Field Sev Customer Reserved Facility Code

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.SeverityLevel.STATUS_SEVERITY_WARNING
member.summary: Indicates a warning NTSTATUS value, such as STATUS_DEVICE_PAPER_EMPTY.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.SeverityLevel.STATUS_SEVERITY_ERROR
member.summary: Indicates an error NTSTATUS value, such as STATUS_INSUFFICIENT_RESOURCES for a FinalStatus value or IO_ERR_CONFIGURATION_ERROR for an ErrorCode value in error log packets.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.CompareTo(Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus)
member.summary: Compares the current object with another object of the same type.
member.param: An object to compare with this object.
member.returns: A value that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has the following meanings: Value Meaning Less than zero This object is less than the parameter.Zero This object is equal to . Greater than zero This object is greater than .

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.CompareTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares the current instance with another object of the same type and returns an integer that indicates whether the current instance precedes, follows, or occurs in the same position in the sort order as the other object.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns: A value that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has these meanings: Value Meaning Less than zero This instance precedes in the sort order. Zero This instance occurs in the same position in the sort order as . Greater than zero This instance follows in the sort order.

This was done because the file system encountered a failure on a member of the fault-tolerant volume but was unable to reassign the failing area of the device.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_FT_WRITE_RECOVERY

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_ALLOTTED_SPACE_EXCEEDED
member.summary: When a block of memory is allotted for future updates, such as the memory allocated to hold discretionary access control and primary group information, successive updates might exceed the amount of memory originally allotted. Because a quota might already have been charged to several processes that have handles to the object, it is not reasonable to alter the size of the allocated memory. Instead, a request that requires more memory than has been allotted must fail and the STATUS_ALLOTTED_SPACE_EXCEEDED error returned.

member.summary: Insufficient system resources exist to complete the API.

member.summary: There are bad blocks (sectors) on the hard disk.

member.summary: An access to a user buffer failed at an expected point in time. This code is defined because the caller does not want to accept STATUS_ACCESS_VIOLATION in its filter.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_UNEXPECTED_IO_ERROR
member.summary: If an I/O error that is not defined in the standard FsRtl filter is returned, it is converted to the following error, which is guaranteed to be in the filter. In this case, information is lost; however, the filter correctly handles the exception.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_UNEXPECTED_MM_CREATE_ERR
member.summary: If an MM error that is not defined in the standard FsRtl filter is returned, it is converted to one of the following errors, which are guaranteed to be in the filter. In this case, information is lost; however, the filter correctly handles the exception.

member.summary: If an MM error that is not defined in the standard FsRtl filter is returned, it is converted to one of the following errors, which are guaranteed to be in the filter. In this case, information is lost; however, the filter correctly handles the exception.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_UNEXPECTED_MM_EXTEND_ERR
member.summary: If an MM error that is not defined in the standard FsRtl filter is returned, it is converted to one of the following errors, which are guaranteed to be in the filter. In this case, information is lost; however, the filter correctly handles the exception.

member.summary: A requested opened file is not a directory.

member.summary: The logon session is not in a state that is consistent with the requested operation.

member.summary: The user attempted to force close the files on a redirected drive, but there were opened directories on the drive, and the user did not specify a sufficient level of force.

member.summary: RtlFindMessage could not locate the requested message ID in the message table resource.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_PROCESS_IS_TERMINATING
member.summary: An attempt was made to duplicate an object handle into or out of an exiting process.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_INVALID_LOGON_TYPE
member.summary: Indicates an invalid value has been provided for the LogonType requested.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_NO_GUID_TRANSLATION
member.summary: Indicates that an attempt was made to assign protection to a file system file or directory and one of the SIDs in the security descriptor could not be translated into a GUID that could be stored by the file system. This causes the protection attempt to fail, which might cause a file creation attempt to fail.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_CANNOT_IMPERSONATE
member.summary: Indicates that an attempt has been made to impersonate via a named pipe that has not yet been read from.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_IMAGE_ALREADY_LOADED
member.summary: Indicates that the specified image is already loaded.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_NO_LDT
member.summary: Indicates that an attempt was made to change the size of the LDT for a process that has no LDT.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_INVALID_LDT_SIZE
member.summary: Indicates that an attempt was made to grow an LDT by setting its size, or that the size was not an even number of selectors.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_INVALID_LDT_OFFSET
member.summary: Indicates that the starting value for the LDT information was not an integral multiple of the selector size.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_INVALID_LDT_DESCRIPTOR
member.summary: Indicates that the user supplied an invalid descriptor when trying to set up LDT descriptors.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_INVALID_IMAGE_NE_FORMAT
member.summary: The specified image file did not have the correct format. It appears to be NE format.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_RXACT_INVALID_STATE
member.summary: Indicates that the transaction state of a registry subtree is incompatible with the requested operation. For example, a request has been made to start a new transaction with one already in progress, or a request has been made to apply a transaction when one is not currently in progress.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_RXACT_COMMIT_FAILURE
member.summary: Indicates an error has occurred during a registry transaction commit. The database has been left in an unknown, but probably inconsistent, state. The state of the registry transaction is left as COMMITTING.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_MAPPED_FILE_SIZE_ZERO
member.summary: An attempt was made to map a file of size zero with the maximum size specified as zero.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_TOO_MANY_OPENED_FILES
member.summary: Too many files are opened on a remote server. This error should only be returned by the Windows redirector on a remote drive.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_CANCELLED
member.summary: The I/O request was canceled.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_CANNOT_DELETE
member.summary: An attempt has been made to remove a file or directory that cannot be deleted.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_INVALID_COMPUTER_NAME
member.summary: Indicates a name that was specified as a remote computer name is syntactically invalid.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_FILE_DELETED
member.summary: An I/O request other than close was performed on a file after it was deleted, which can only happen to a request that did not complete before the last handle was closed via NtClose.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_SPECIAL_ACCOUNT
member.summary: Indicates an operation that is incompatible with built-in accounts has been attempted on a built-in (special) SAM account. For example, built-in accounts cannot be deleted.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_SPECIAL_GROUP
member.summary: The operation requested cannot be performed on the specified group because it is a built-in special group.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_SPECIAL_USER
member.summary: The operation requested cannot be performed on the specified user because it is a built-in special user.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_MEMBERS_PRIMARY_GROUP
member.summary: Indicates a member cannot be removed from a group because the group is currently the member's primary group.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_FILE_CLOSED
member.summary: An I/O request other than close and several other special case operations was attempted using a file object that had already been closed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_TOO_MANY_THREADS
member.summary: Indicates a process has too many threads to perform the requested action. For example, assignment of a primary token can be performed only when a process has zero or one threads.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_THREAD_NOT_IN_PROCESS
member.summary: An attempt was made to operate on a thread within a specific process, but the specified thread is not in the specified process.

member.summary: The protected output cannot enable the HDCP system because it does not support it.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_OUTPUT_DOES_NOT_SUPPORT_ACP
member.summary: The protected output cannot enable analog copy protection because it does not support it.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_OUTPUT_DOES_NOT_SUPPORT_CGMSA
member.summary: The protected output cannot enable the CGMS-A protection technology because it does not support it.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_HDCP_SRM_NEVER_SET
member.summary: DxgkDdiOPMGetInformation() cannot return the version of the SRM being used because the application never successfully passed an SRM to the protected output.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_RESOLUTION_TOO_HIGH
member.summary: DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput() cannot enable the specified output protection technology because the output's screen resolution is too high.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_ALL_HDCP_HARDWARE_ALREADY_IN_USE
member.summary: DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput() cannot enable HDCP because other physical outputs are using the display adapter's HDCP hardware.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_PROTECTED_OUTPUT_NO_LONGER_EXISTS
member.summary: The operating system asynchronously destroyed this OPM-protected output because the operating system state changed. This error typically occurs because the monitor PDO associated with this protected output was removed or stopped, the protected output's session became a nonconsole session, or the protected output's desktop became inactive.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_SESSION_TYPE_CHANGE_IN_PROGRESS
member.summary: OPM functions cannot be called when a session is changing its type. Three types of sessions currently exist: console, disconnected, and remote (RDP or ICA).

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_PROTECTED_OUTPUT_DOES_NOT_HAVE_COPP_SEMANTICS
member.summary: The DxgkDdiOPMGetCOPPCompatibleInformation, DxgkDdiOPMGetInformation, or DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput function failed. This error is returned only if a protected output has OPM semantics. DxgkDdiOPMGetCOPPCompatibleInformation always returns this error if a protected output has OPM semantics. DxgkDdiOPMGetInformation returns this error code if the caller requested COPP-specific information. DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput returns this error when the caller tries to use a COPP-specific command.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_INVALID_INFORMATION_REQUEST
member.summary: The DxgkDdiOPMGetInformation and DxgkDdiOPMGetCOPPCompatibleInformation functions return this error code if the passed-in sequence number is not the expected sequence number or the passed-in OMAC value is invalid.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_DRIVER_INTERNAL_ERROR
member.summary: The function failed because an unexpected error occurred inside a display driver.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_PROTECTED_OUTPUT_DOES_NOT_HAVE_OPM_SEMANTICS
member.summary: The DxgkDdiOPMGetCOPPCompatibleInformation, DxgkDdiOPMGetInformation, or DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput function failed. This error is returned only if a protected output has COPP semantics. DxgkDdiOPMGetCOPPCompatibleInformation returns this error code if the caller requested OPM-specific information. DxgkDdiOPMGetInformation always returns this error if a protected output has COPP semantics. DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput returns this error when the caller tries to use an OPM-specific command.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_SIGNALING_NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: The DxgkDdiOPMGetCOPPCompatibleInformation and DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput functions return this error if the display driver does not support the DXGKMDT_OPM_GET_ACP_AND_CGMSA_SIGNALING and DXGKMDT_OPM_SET_ACP_AND_CGMSA_SIGNALING GUIDs.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_OPM_INVALID_CONFIGURATION_REQUEST
member.summary: The DxgkDdiOPMConfigureProtectedOutput function returns this error code if the passed-in sequence number is not the expected sequence number or the passed-in OMAC value is invalid.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_I2C_NOT_SUPPORTED
member.summary: The monitor connected to the specified video output does not have an I2C bus.

member.summary: An internal error caused an operation to fail.

member.summary: An operation failed because a DDC/CI message had an invalid value in its command field.

member.summary: This error occurred because a DDC/CI message had an invalid value in its length field.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_DDCCI_INVALID_MESSAGE_CHECKSUM
member.summary: This error occurred because the value in a DDC/CI message's checksum field did not match the message's computed checksum value. This error implies that the data was corrupted while it was being transmitted from a monitor to a computer.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_INVALID_PHYSICAL_MONITOR_HANDLE
member.summary: This function failed because an invalid monitor handle was passed to it.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_MONITOR_NO_LONGER_EXISTS
member.summary: The operating system asynchronously destroyed the monitor that corresponds to this handle because the operating system's state changed. This error typically occurs because the monitor PDO associated with this handle was removed or stopped, or a display mode change occurred. A display mode change occurs when Windows sends a WM_DISPLAYCHANGE message to applications.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_ONLY_CONSOLE_SESSION_SUPPORTED
member.summary: This function can be used only if a program is running in the local console session. It cannot be used if a program is running on a remote desktop session or on a terminal server session.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.NTStatus.STATUS_GRAPHICS_DISPLAY_DEVICE_NOT_ATTACHED_TO_DESKTOP
member.summary: The function failed because the specified GDI display device was not attached to the Windows desktop.

member.summary: This function does not support GDI mirroring display devices because GDI mirroring display devices do not have any physical monitors associated with them.

member.summary: The data for the counter was returned successfully, but is unchanged from the last time the counter was read.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_NEW_DATA
member.summary: The data for the counter was returned successfully and is different from the last time the counter was read. PDH_CSTATUS_NEW_DATA can be returned on a rate counter even if the resulting rate is the same as the last sample. This is because the raw data value that is used in the determination of this status value has changed, not the computed rate.

member.summary: Cannot change set default real-time data source. There are real-time query sessions collecting counter data.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_COUNTER_ALREADY_IN_QUERY
member.summary: The PDH counter already in query

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_BAD_COUNTERNAME
member.summary: The counter path format is incorrect.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_INVALID_DATA
member.summary: The counter was successfully found, but the data returned is not valid. This error can occur if the counter value is less than the previous value. (Because counter values always increment, the counter value rolls over to zero when it reaches its maximum value.) Another possible cause is a system timer that is not correct.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_ITEM_NOT_VALIDATED
member.summary: The counter has been added to the query, but has not been validated nor accessed. No additional status information on this counter is available.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_NO_COUNTER
member.summary: The specified counter was not found in the specified object. If this status is returned when the counter is being added, then the counter is not added to the query. If this status is returned after data collection, the data for that counter is invalid. Each time the data is requested, PDH tries to obtain this counter data.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_NO_COUNTERNAME
member.summary: No counter name was specified in the query.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_NO_INSTANCE
member.summary: The specified instance was not found in the object. If this status is returned while the counter is being added to the query, the counter is successfully added to the query, but no data is available until the specific instance appears and a successful status is returned.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_NO_MACHINE
member.summary: PDH was unable to connect to the computer specified in the counter path. If this status is returned when the counter is being added, the counter is not completely initialized. Each time the query is updated, PDH retries the connection. When the connection is established, normal data collection resumes.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_CSTATUS_NO_OBJECT
member.summary: The specified computer was found, but the specified performance object was found on the computer. If this status is returned when the counter is being added, the specified counter is not included in the query. If this status is returned by an active counter, the data for that counter is invalid. Each time the data is requested, PDH tries to obtain this counter data.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.PDH_DATA_SOURCE_IS_LOG_FILE

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.ERROR_WINHTTP_CLIENT_AUTH_CERT_NEEDED
member.summary:
The server requires SSL client Authentication. The application retrieves the list of certificate issuers by calling WinHttpQueryOption with the WINHTTP_OPTION_CLIENT_CERT_ISSUER_LIST option. For more information, see the WINHTTP_OPTION_CLIENT_CERT_ISSUER_LIST option.
If the server requests the client certificate, but does not require it, the application can alternately call WinHttpSetOption with the WINHTTP_OPTION_CLIENT_CERT_CONTEXT option. In this case, the application specifies the WINHTTP_NO_CLIENT_CERT_CONTEXT macro in the lpBuffer parameter of WinHttpSetOption. For more information, see the WINHTTP_OPTION_CLIENT_CERT_CONTEXT option.
Windows Server 2003 with SP1 and Windows XP with SP2: This error is not supported.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.ERROR_WINHTTP_CLIENT_CERT_NO_ACCESS_PRIVATE_KEY
member.summary:
The application does not have the required privileges to access the private key associated with the client certificate.
Windows Server 2003 with SP1 and Windows XP with SP2: This error is not supported.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.ERROR_WINHTTP_CLIENT_CERT_NO_PRIVATE_KEY
member.summary:
The context for the SSL client certificate does not have a private key associated with it. The client certificate may have been imported to the computer without the private key.
Windows Server 2003 with SP1 and Windows XP with SP2: This error is not supported.

member.summary: Indicates that a required certificate is not within its validity period when verifying against the current system clock or the timestamp in the signed file, or that the validity periods of the certification chain do not nest correctly (equivalent to a CERT_E_EXPIRED or a CERT_E_VALIDITYPERIODNESTING error).

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.ERROR_WINHTTP_SECURE_CHANNEL_ERROR
member.summary: Indicates that an error occurred having to do with a secure channel (equivalent to error codes that begin with "SEC_E_" and "SEC_I_" listed in the "winerror.h" header file).

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.Win32Error.ERROR_WINHTTP_SECURE_FAILURE
member.summary: One or more errors were found in the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificate sent by the server. To determine what type of error was encountered, check for a WINHTTP_CALLBACK_STATUS_SECURE_FAILURE notification in a status callback function. For more information, see WINHTTP_STATUS_CALLBACK.

member.summary: Indicates that a certificate is invalid (equivalent to errors such as CERT_E_ROLE, CERT_E_PATHLENCONST, CERT_E_CRITICAL, CERT_E_PURPOSE, CERT_E_ISSUERCHAINING, CERT_E_MALFORMED and CERT_E_CHAINING).

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMICM.DMICM_CONTRAST
member.summary: Color matching should optimize for color contrast. This value is the most appropriate choice for scanned or photographic images when dithering is desired.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMICM.DMICM_COLORIMETRIC
member.summary: Color matching should optimize to match the exact color requested. This value is most appropriate for use with business logos or other images when an exact color match is desired.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMICM.DMICM_ABS_COLORIMETRIC
member.summary: Color matching should optimize to match the exact color requested without white point mapping. This value is most appropriate for use with proofing.

member.summary: The printer resolution.

member.summary: Use draft resolution (96 DPI).

member.summary: Use low resolution (150 DPI).

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.DMTT
member.summary: Specifies how TrueType fonts should be printed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMTT.DMTT_BITMAP
member.summary: Prints TrueType fonts as graphics. This is the default action for dot-matrix printers.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMTT.DMTT_DOWNLOAD
member.summary: Downloads TrueType fonts as soft fonts. This is the default action for Hewlett-Packard printers that use Printer Control Language (PCL).

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMTT.DMTT_SUBDEV
member.summary: Substitute device fonts for TrueType fonts. This is the default action for PostScript printers.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DMTT.DMTT_DOWNLOAD_OUTLINE
member.summary: Downloads TrueType fonts as outline soft fonts.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE
member.summary: The DEVMODE data structure contains information about the initialization and environment of a printer or a display device.
member.remarks: A device driver's private data follows the public portion of the DEVMODE structure. The size of the public data can vary for different versions of the structure. The dmSize member specifies the number of bytes of public data, and the dmDriverExtra member specifies the number of bytes of private data.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.DM_SPECVERSION
member.summary: Version for XP and later.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmDeviceName
member.summary: A zero-terminated character array that specifies the "friendly" name of the printer or display; for example, "PCL/HP LaserJet" in the case of PCL/HP LaserJet. This string is unique among device drivers. Note that this name may be truncated to fit in the dmDeviceName array.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmSpecVersion
member.summary: The version number of the initialization data specification on which the structure is based. To ensure the correct version is used for any operating system, use DM_SPECVERSION.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmDriverVersion
member.summary: The driver version number assigned by the driver developer.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmSize
member.summary: Specifies the size, in bytes, of the DEVMODE structure, not including any private driver-specific data that might follow the structure's public members. Set this member to to indicate the version of the DEVMODE structure being used.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmDriverExtra
member.summary: Contains the number of bytes of private driver-data that follow this structure. If a device driver does not use device-specific information, set this member to zero.

summary.para: Specifies whether certain members of the DEVMODE structure have been initialized. If a member is initialized, its corresponding bit is set, otherwise the bit is clear. A driver supports only those DEVMODE members that are appropriate for the printer or display technology.
The following values are defined, and are listed here with the corresponding structure members.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.Union
member.summary: DUMMYUNIONNAME

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmOrientation
member.summary: For printer devices only, selects the orientation of the paper. This member can be either DMORIENT_PORTRAIT (1) or DMORIENT_LANDSCAPE (2).

summary.para: For printer devices only, selects the size of the paper to print on. This member can be set to zero if the length and width of the paper are both set by the dmPaperLength and dmPaperWidth members. Otherwise, the dmPaperSize member can be set to a device specific value greater than or equal to DMPAPER_USER or to one of the following predefined values.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPaperLength
member.summary: For printer devices only, overrides the length of the paper specified by the dmPaperSize member, either for custom paper sizes or for devices such as dot-matrix printers that can print on a page of arbitrary length. These values, along with all other values in this structure that specify a physical length, are in tenths of a millimeter.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPaperWidth
member.summary: For printer devices only, overrides the width of the paper specified by the dmPaperSize member.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmScale
member.summary: Specifies the factor by which the printed output is to be scaled. The apparent page size is scaled from the physical page size by a factor of dmScale /100. For example, a letter-sized page with a dmScale value of 50 would contain as much data as a page of 17- by 22-inches because the output text and graphics would be half their original height and width.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmCopies
member.summary: Selects the number of copies printed if the device supports multiple-page copies.

summary.para: Specifies the paper source. To retrieve a list of the available paper sources for a printer, use the DeviceCapabilities function with the DC_BINS flag.
This member can be one of the following values, or it can be a device-specific value greater than or equal to DMBIN_USER.
Specifies the printer resolution. There are four predefined device-independent values:
If a positive value is specified, it specifies the number of dots per inch (DPI) and is therefore device dependent.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPosition
member.summary: For display devices only, a POINTL structure that indicates the positional coordinates of the display device in reference to the desktop area. The primary display device is always located at coordinates (0,0).

summary.para: For display devices only, the orientation at which images should be presented. If DM_DISPLAYORIENTATION is not set, this member must be zero. If DM_DISPLAYORIENTATION is set, this member must be one of the following values

item.term: The display orientation is the natural orientation of the display device; it should be used as the default.
The display orientation is rotated 90 degrees (measured clockwise) from DMDO_DEFAULT.
The display orientation is rotated 180 degrees (measured clockwise) from DMDO_DEFAULT.
The display orientation is rotated 270 degrees (measured clockwise) from DMDO_DEFAULT.

summary.para: To determine whether the display orientation is portrait or landscape orientation, check the ratio of dmPelsWidth to dmPelsHeight.
Windows 2000: Not supported.

For fixed-resolution display devices only, how the display presents a low-resolution mode on a higher-resolution display. For example, if a display device's resolution is fixed at 1024 x 768 pixels but its mode is set to 640 x 480 pixels, the device can either display a 640 x 480 image somewhere in the interior of the 1024 x 768 screen space or stretch the 640 x 480 image to fill the larger screen space. If DM_DISPLAYFIXEDOUTPUT is not set, this member must be zero. If DM_DISPLAYFIXEDOUTPUT is set, this member must be one of the following values.

item.term: The low-resolution image is centered in the larger screen space.
The low-resolution image is stretched to fill the larger screen space.

summary.para: Windows 2000: Not supported.
Switches between color and monochrome on color printers. The following are the possible values:
Selects duplex or double-sided printing for printers capable of duplex printing. Following are the possible values.

item.term: Short-edge binding, that is, the long edge of the page is horizontal.
Long-edge binding, that is, the long edge of the page is vertical.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmYResolution
member.summary: Specifies the y-resolution, in dots per inch, of the printer. If the printer initializes this member, the dmPrintQuality member specifies the x-resolution, in dots per inch, of the printer.

summary.para: Specifies how TrueType fonts should be printed. This member can be one of the following values.

item.term: Prints TrueType fonts as graphics. This is the default action for dot-matrix printers.
Downloads TrueType fonts as soft fonts. This is the default action for Hewlett-Packard printers that use Printer Control Language (PCL).
Downloads TrueType fonts as outline soft fonts.
Substitutes device fonts for TrueType fonts. This is the default action for PostScript printers.

summary.para: Specifies whether collation should be used when printing multiple copies. (This member is ignored unless the printer driver indicates support for collation by setting the dmFields member to DM_COLLATE.) This member can be one of the following values.

item.term: Do not collate when printing multiple copies.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmFormName
member.summary: A zero-terminated character array that specifies the name of the form to use; for example, "Letter" or "Legal". A complete set of names can be retrieved by using the EnumForms function.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmLogPixels
member.summary: The number of pixels per logical inch. Printer drivers do not use this member.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmBitsPerPel
member.summary: Specifies the color resolution, in bits per pixel, of the display device (for example: 4 bits for 16 colors, 8 bits for 256 colors, or 16 bits for 65,536 colors). Display drivers use this member, for example, in the ChangeDisplaySettings function. Printer drivers do not use this member.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPelsWidth
member.summary: Specifies the width, in pixels, of the visible device surface. Display drivers use this member, for example, in the ChangeDisplaySettings function. Printer drivers do not use this member.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPelsHeight
member.summary: Specifies the height, in pixels, of the visible device surface. Display drivers use this member, for example, in the ChangeDisplaySettings function. Printer drivers do not use this member.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.Union2
member.summary: DUMMYUNIONNAME2

summary.para: Specifies the device's display mode. This member can be a combination of the following values.

item.term: Specifies that the display is a noncolor device. If this flag is not set, color is assumed.
Specifies that the display mode is interlaced. If the flag is not set, noninterlaced is assumed.

summary.para: Display drivers use this member, for example, in the ChangeDisplaySettings function. Printer drivers do not use this member.
Specifies where the NUP is done. It can be one of the following.

item.term: The print spooler does the NUP.

summary.para: Specifies the frequency, in hertz (cycles per second), of the display device in a particular mode. This value is also known as the display device's vertical refresh rate. Display drivers use this member. It is used, for example, in the ChangeDisplaySettings function. Printer drivers do not use this member.

When you call the EnumDisplaySettings function, the dmDisplayFrequency member may return with the value 0 or 1. These values represent the display hardware's default refresh rate. This default rate is typically set by switches on a display card or computer motherboard, or by a configuration program that does not use display functions such as ChangeDisplaySettings.

Specifies how ICM is handled. For a non-ICM application, this member determines if ICM is enabled or disabled. For ICM applications, the system examines this member to determine how to handle ICM support. This member can be one of the following predefined values, or a driver-defined value greater than or equal to the value of DMICMMETHOD_USER.

item.term: Specifies that ICM is handled by Windows.
Specifies that ICM is handled by the device driver.
Specifies that ICM is handled by the destination device.

summary.para: The printer driver must provide a user interface for setting this member. Most printer drivers support only the DMICMMETHOD_SYSTEM or DMICMMETHOD_NONE value. Drivers for PostScript printers support all values.

Specifies which color matching method, or intent, should be used by default. This member is primarily for non-ICM applications. ICM applications can establish intents by using the ICM functions. This member can be one of the following predefined values, or a driver defined value greater than or equal to the value of DMICM_USER.

item.term: Color matching should optimize to match the exact color requested without white point mapping. This value is most appropriate for use with proofing.
Color matching should optimize to match the exact color requested. This value is most appropriate for use with business logos or other images when an exact color match is desired.
Color matching should optimize for color contrast. This value is the most appropriate choice for scanned or photographic images when dithering is desired.
Color matching should optimize for color saturation. This value is the most appropriate choice for business graphs when dithering is not desired.

summary.para: Specifies the type of media being printed on. The member can be one of the following predefined values, or a driver-defined value greater than or equal to the value of DMMEDIA_USER.
To retrieve a list of the available media types for a printer, use the DeviceCapabilities function with the DC_MEDIATYPES flag.
Specifies how dithering is to be done. The member can be one of the following predefined values, or a driver-defined value greater than or equal to the value of DMDITHER_USER.

item.term: Line art dithering, a special dithering method that produces well defined borders between black, white, and gray scaling. It is not suitable for images that include continuous graduations in intensity and hue, such as scanned photographs.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmReserved1
member.summary: Not used; must be zero.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmReserved2
member.summary: Not used; must be zero.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPanningWidth
member.summary: This member must be zero.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.dmPanningHeight
member.summary: This member must be zero.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.DEVMODE.Default
member.summary: A default value with dmSize and dmSpecVersion set.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily
member.summary: Font families describe the look of a font in a general way. They are intended for specifying fonts when the exact typeface desired is not available.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily.FF_DONTCARE
member.summary: Use default font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily.FF_ROMAN
member.summary: Fonts with variable stroke width (proportional) and with serifs. MS Serif is an example.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily.FF_SWISS
member.summary: Fonts with variable stroke width (proportional) and without serifs. MS Sans Serif is an example.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily.FF_MODERN
member.summary: Fonts with constant stroke width (monospace), with or without serifs. Monospace fonts are usually modern. Pica, Elite, and CourierNew are examples.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily.FF_SCRIPT
member.summary: Fonts designed to look like handwriting. Script and Cursive are examples.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontFamily.FF_DECORATIVE
member.summary: Novelty fonts. Old English is an example.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch
member.summary: Specifies information about the pitch, the technology, and the family of a physical font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.DEFAULT_PITCH
member.summary: The default pitch, which is implementation-dependent.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.FIXED_PITCH
member.summary: A fixed pitch, which means that all the characters in the font occupy the same width when output in a string.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.VARIABLE_PITCH
member.summary: A variable pitch, which means that the characters in the font occupy widths that are proportional to the actual widths of the glyphs when output in a string. For example, the "i" and space characters usually have much smaller widths than a "W" or "O" character.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.MONO_FONT
member.summary: The mono font/

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.TMPF_FIXED_PITCH
member.summary: If this bit is set the font is a variable pitch font. If this bit is clear the font is a fixed pitch font. Note very carefully that those meanings are the opposite of what the constant name implies.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.TMPF_VECTOR
member.summary: If this bit is set the font is a vector font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.TMPF_TRUETYPE
member.summary: If this bit is set the font is a TrueType font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FontPitch.TMPF_DEVICE
member.summary: If this bit is set the font is a device font.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision
member.summary: The clipping precision defines how to clip characters that are partially outside the clipping region.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_CHARACTER_PRECIS
member.summary: Not used.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_DEFAULT_PRECIS
member.summary: Specifies default clipping behavior.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_DFA_DISABLE
member.summary: Windows XP SP1: Turns off font association for the font. Note that this flag is not guaranteed to have any effect on any platform after Windows Server 2003.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_DFA_OVERRIDE
member.summary: Turns off font association for the font. This is identical to CLIP_DFA_DISABLE, but it can have problems in some situations; the recommended flag to use is CLIP_DFA_DISABLE.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_EMBEDDED
member.summary: You must specify this flag to use an embedded read-only font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_LH_ANGLES
member.summary: When this value is used, the rotation for all fonts depends on whether the orientation of the coordinate system is left-handed or right-handed. If not used, device fonts always rotate counterclockwise, but the rotation of other fonts is dependent on the orientation of the coordinate system.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_MASK
member.summary: Not used.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_STROKE_PRECIS
member.summary: Not used by the font mapper, but is returned when raster, vector, or TrueType fonts are enumerated. For compatibility, this value is always returned when enumerating fonts.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontClippingPrecision.CLIP_TT_ALWAYS
member.summary: Not used.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision
member.summary: The output precision. The output precision defines how closely the output must match the requested font's height, width, character orientation, escapement, pitch, and font type.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_CHARACTER_PRECIS
member.summary: Not used.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_DEFAULT_PRECIS
member.summary: Specifies the default font mapper behavior.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_DEVICE_PRECIS
member.summary: Instructs the font mapper to choose a Device font when the system contains multiple fonts with the same name.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_OUTLINE_PRECIS
member.summary: This value instructs the font mapper to choose from TrueType and other outline-based fonts.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_PS_ONLY_PRECIS
member.summary: Instructs the font mapper to choose from only PostScript fonts. If there are no PostScript fonts installed in the system, the font mapper returns to default behavior.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_RASTER_PRECIS
member.summary: Instructs the font mapper to choose a raster font when the system contains multiple fonts with the same name.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_SCREEN_OUTLINE_PRECIS
member.summary: A value that specifies a preference for TrueType and other outline fonts.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_STRING_PRECIS
member.summary: This value is not used by the font mapper, but it is returned when raster fonts are enumerated.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_STROKE_PRECIS
member.summary: This value is not used by the font mapper, but it is returned when TrueType, other outline-based fonts, and vector fonts are enumerated.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_TT_ONLY_PRECIS
member.summary: Instructs the font mapper to choose from only TrueType fonts. If there are no TrueType fonts installed in the system, the font mapper returns to default behavior.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputPrecision.OUT_TT_PRECIS
member.summary: Instructs the font mapper to choose a TrueType font when the system contains multiple fonts with the same name.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality
member.summary: The output quality defines how carefully the graphics device interface (GDI) must attempt to match the logical-font attributes to those of an actual physical font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.DEFAULT_QUALITY
member.summary: Appearance of the font does not matter.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.DRAFT_QUALITY
member.summary: Appearance of the font is less important than when PROOF_QUALITY is used. For GDI raster fonts, scaling is enabled, which means that more font sizes are available, but the quality may be lower. Bold, italic, underline, and strikeout fonts are synthesized if necessary.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.PROOF_QUALITY
member.summary: Character quality of the font is more important than exact matching of the logical-font attributes. For GDI raster fonts, scaling is disabled and the font closest in size is chosen. Although the chosen font size may not be mapped exactly when PROOF_QUALITY is used, the quality of the font is high and there is no distortion of appearance. Bold, italic, underline, and strikeout fonts are synthesized if necessary.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.NONANTIALIASED_QUALITY
member.summary: Font is never antialiased.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.ANTIALIASED_QUALITY
member.summary: Font is always antialiased if the font supports it and the size of the font is not too small or too large.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.CLEARTYPE_QUALITY
member.summary: If set, text is rendered (when possible) using ClearType antialiasing method. The font quality is given less importance than maintaining the text size.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LogFontOutputQuality.CLEARTYPE_NATURAL_QUALITY
member.summary: If set, text is rendered (when possible) using ClearType antialiasing method. The font quality is given more importance than maintaining the text size.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT
member.summary: The LOGFONT structure defines the attributes of a font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfHeight
member.summary:
The height, in logical units, of the font's character cell or character. The character height value (also known as the em height) is the character cell height value minus the internal-leading value. The font mapper interprets the value specified in lfHeight in the following manner.
Value Meaning
> 0 The font mapper transforms this value into device units and matches it against the cell height of the available fonts.
0 The font mapper uses a default height value when it searches for a match.
< 0 The font mapper transforms this value into device units and matches its absolute value against the character height of the available fonts.
For all height comparisons, the font mapper looks for the largest font that does not exceed the requested size.
This mapping occurs when the font is used for the first time.
For the MM_TEXT mapping mode, you can use the following formula to specify a height for a font with a specified point size:

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfWidth
member.summary: The average width, in logical units, of characters in the font. If lfWidth is zero, the aspect ratio of the device is matched against the digitization aspect ratio of the available fonts to find the closest match, determined by the absolute value of the difference.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfEscapement
member.summary:
The angle, in tenths of degrees, between the escapement vector and the x-axis of the device. The escapement vector is parallel to the base line of a row of text.
When the graphics mode is set to GM_ADVANCED, you can specify the escapement angle of the string independently of the orientation angle of the string's characters.
When the graphics mode is set to GM_COMPATIBLE, lfEscapement specifies both the escapement and orientation. You should set lfEscapement and lfOrientation to the same value.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfOrientation
member.summary: The angle, in tenths of degrees, between each character's base line and the x-axis of the device.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT._lfWeight
member.summary: The weight of the font in the range 0 through 1000. For example, 400 is normal and 700 is bold. If this value is zero, a default weight is used.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfItalic
member.summary: An italic font if set to TRUE.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfUnderline
member.summary: An underlined font if set to TRUE.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfStrikeOut
member.summary: A strikeout font if set to TRUE.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfCharSet
member.summary: The character set.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfOutPrecision
member.summary: The output precision. The output precision defines how closely the output must match the requested font's height, width, character orientation, escapement, pitch, and font type.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfClipPrecision
member.summary: The clipping precision. The clipping precision defines how to clip characters that are partially outside the clipping region.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfQuality
member.summary: The output quality. The output quality defines how carefully the graphics device interface (GDI) must attempt to match the logical-font attributes to those of an actual physical font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfPitchAndFamily
member.summary: The pitch and family of the font.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT._lfFaceName
member.summary: A null-terminated string that specifies the typeface name of the font. The length of this string must not exceed 32 TCHAR values, including the terminating NULL. The EnumFontFamiliesEx function can be used to enumerate the typeface names of all currently available fonts. If lfFaceName is an empty string, GDI uses the first font that matches the other specified attributes.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.FontFamily
member.summary: Gets or sets the font family.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfFaceName
member.summary: A string that specifies the typeface name of the font. The length of this string must not exceed 31 characters. The EnumFontFamiliesEx function can be used to enumerate the typeface names of all currently available fonts. If lfFaceName is an empty string, GDI uses the first font that matches the other specified attributes.
member.value: The face name of the font.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LOGFONT.lfWeight
member.summary: The weight of the font in the range 0 through 1000. For example, 400 is normal and 700 is bold. If this value is zero, a default weight is used.

member.summary: Gets or sets the font pitch.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.ACCESS_SYSTEM_SECURITY
member.summary: Controls the ability to get or set the SACL in an object's security descriptor. The system grants this access right only if the SE_SECURITY_NAME privilege is enabled in the access token of the requesting thread.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.DELETE
member.summary: The right to delete the object.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.GENERIC_ALL
member.summary: All possible access rights.

member.summary: Execute access.

member.summary: Read access.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.GENERIC_WRITE
member.summary: Write access.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.MAXIMUM_ALLOWED
member.summary: Request that the object be opened with all the access rights that are valid for the caller.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.READ_CONTROL
member.summary: The right to read the information in the object's security descriptor, not including the information in the system access control list (SACL).

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.SPECIFIC_RIGHTS_ALL
member.summary: The specific rights all

member.summary: Combines DELETE, READ_CONTROL, WRITE_DAC, WRITE_OWNER, and SYNCHRONIZE access.

member.summary: Currently defined to equal READ_CONTROL.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.STANDARD_RIGHTS_READ

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.STANDARD_RIGHTS_REQUIRED
member.summary: Combines DELETE, READ_CONTROL, WRITE_DAC, and WRITE_OWNER access.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.STANDARD_RIGHTS_WRITE
member.summary: Currently defined to equal READ_CONTROL.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.SYNCHRONIZE
member.summary: The right to use the object for synchronization. This enables a thread to wait until the object is in the signaled state. Some object types do not support this access right.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.WRITE_DAC
member.summary: The right to modify the discretionary access control list (DACL) in the object's security descriptor.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.ACCESS_MASK.WRITE_OWNER
member.summary: The right to change the owner in the object's security descriptor.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes
member.summary: File attributes are metadata values stored by the file system on disk and are used by the system and are available to developers via various file I/O APIs.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_READONLY
member.summary: A file that is read-only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to it or delete it. This attribute is not honored on directories. For more information, see You cannot view or change the Read-only or the System attributes of folders in Windows Server 2003, in Windows XP, in Windows Vista or in Windows 7.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_HIDDEN
member.summary: The file or directory is hidden. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SYSTEM
member.summary: A file or directory that the operating system uses a part of, or uses exclusively.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DIRECTORY
member.summary: The handle that identifies a directory.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ARCHIVE
member.summary: A file or directory that is an archive file or directory. Applications typically use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal .

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DEVICE
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NORMAL
member.summary: A file that does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only when used alone.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_TEMPORARY
member.summary: A file that is being used for temporary storage. File systems avoid writing data back to mass storage if sufficient cache memory is available, because typically, an application deletes a temporary file after the handle is closed. In that scenario, the system can entirely avoid writing the data. Otherwise, the data is written after the handle is closed.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SPARSE_FILE
member.summary: A file that is a sparse file.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: A file or directory that has an associated reparse point, or a file that is a symbolic link.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_COMPRESSED
member.summary: A file or directory that is compressed. For a file, all of the data in the file is compressed. For a directory, compression is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_OFFLINE
member.summary: The data of a file is not available immediately. This attribute indicates that the file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, which is the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NOT_CONTENT_INDEXED
member.summary: The file or directory is not to be indexed by the content indexing service.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_ENCRYPTED
member.summary: A file or directory that is encrypted. For a file, all data streams in the file are encrypted. For a directory, encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_INTEGRITY_STREAM
member.summary:
The directory or user data stream is configured with integrity (only supported on ReFS volumes). It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. The integrity setting persists with the file if it's renamed. If a file is copied the destination file will have integrity set if either the source file or destination directory have integrity set.
Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_VIRTUAL
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_NO_SCRUB_DATA
member.summary:
The user data stream not to be read by the background data integrity scanner (AKA scrubber). When set on a directory it only provides inheritance. This flag is only supported on Storage Spaces and ReFS volumes. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.
Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows 7, Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_PINNED
member.summary: Used to prevent the file from being purged from local storage when running low on disk space.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_UNPINNED
member.summary: Indicate that the file is not stored locally.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_RECALL_ON_OPEN
member.summary: This attribute only appears in directory enumeration classes (FILE_DIRECTORY_INFORMATION, FILE_BOTH_DIR_INFORMATION, etc.). When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory has no physical representation on the local system; the item is virtual. Opening the item will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of it to be fetched from a remote store.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_ATTRIBUTE_RECALL_ON_DATA_ACCESS
member.summary: When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory is not fully present locally. For a file that means that not all of its data is on local storage (e.g. it may be sparse with some data still in remote storage). For a directory it means that some of the directory contents are being virtualized from another location. Reading the file / enumerating the directory will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of the file/directory content to be fetched from a remote store. Only kernel-mode callers can set this bit.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_WRITE_THROUGH
member.summary:
Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to disk.
For additional information, see the Caching Behavior section of this topic.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED
member.summary:
The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O.
When subsequent I/O operations are completed on this handle, the event specified in the OVERLAPPED structure will be set to the signaled state.
If this flag is specified, the file can be used for simultaneous read and write operations.
If this flag is not specified, then I/O operations are serialized, even if the calls to the read and write functions specify an OVERLAPPED structure.
For information about considerations when using a file handle created with this flag, see the Synchronous and Asynchronous I/O Handles section of this topic.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING
member.summary:
The file or device is being opened with no system caching for data reads and writes. This flag does not affect hard disk caching or memory mapped files.
There are strict requirements for successfully working with files opened with CreateFile using the FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING flag, for details see File Buffering.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_RANDOM_ACCESS
member.summary:
Access is intended to be random. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching.
This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING.
For more information, see the Caching Behavior section of this topic.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_SEQUENTIAL_SCAN
member.summary:
Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching.
This flag should not be used if read-behind (that is, reverse scans) will be used.
This flag has no effect if the file system does not support cached I/O and FILE_FLAG_NO_BUFFERING.
For more information, see the Caching Behavior section of this topic.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_DELETE_ON_CLOSE
member.summary:
The file is to be deleted immediately after all of its handles are closed, which includes the specified handle and any other open or duplicated handles.
If there are existing open handles to a file, the call fails unless they were all opened with the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode.
Subsequent open requests for the file fail, unless the FILE_SHARE_DELETE share mode is specified.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_BACKUP_SEMANTICS
member.summary:
The file is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation. The system ensures that the calling process overrides file security checks when the process has SE_BACKUP_NAME and SE_RESTORE_NAME privileges. For more information, see Changing Privileges in a Token.
You must set this flag to obtain a handle to a directory. A directory handle can be passed to some functions instead of a file handle. For more information, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_POSIX_SEMANTICS
member.summary: Access will occur according to POSIX rules. This includes allowing multiple files with names, differing only in case, for file systems that support that naming. Use care when using this option, because files created with this flag may not be accessible by applications that are written for MS-DOS or 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_SESSION_AWARE
member.summary:
The file or device is being opened with session awareness. If this flag is not specified, then per-session devices (such as a device using RemoteFX USB Redirection) cannot be opened by processes running in session 0. This flag has no effect for callers not in session 0. This flag is supported only on server editions of Windows.
Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows Server 2008: This flag is not supported before Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary:
Normal reparse point processing will not occur; CreateFile will attempt to open the reparse point. When a file is opened, a file handle is returned, whether or not the filter that controls the reparse point is operational.
This flag cannot be used with the CREATE_ALWAYS flag.
If the file is not a reparse point, then this flag is ignored.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_OPEN_NO_RECALL
member.summary: The file data is requested, but it should continue to be located in remote storage. It should not be transported back to local storage. This flag is for use by remote storage systems.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.FILE_FLAG_FIRST_PIPE_INSTANCE
member.summary: If you attempt to create multiple instances of a pipe with this flag, creation of the first instance succeeds, but creation of the next instance fails with ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_ANONYMOUS
member.summary: Impersonates a client at the Anonymous impersonation level.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_IDENTIFICATION
member.summary: Impersonates a client at the Identification impersonation level.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_IMPERSONATION
member.summary: Impersonate a client at the impersonation level. This is the default behavior if no other flags are specified along with the SECURITY_SQOS_PRESENT flag.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_DELEGATION
member.summary: Impersonates a client at the Delegation impersonation level.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_CONTEXT_TRACKING
member.summary: The security tracking mode is dynamic. If this flag is not specified, the security tracking mode is static.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_EFFECTIVE_ONLY
member.summary:
Only the enabled aspects of the client's security context are available to the server. If you do not specify this flag, all aspects of the client's security context are available.
This allows the client to limit the groups and privileges that a server can use while impersonating the client.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SECURITY_SQOS_PRESENT
member.summary: Include to enable the other SECURITY_ flags.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.LANGID
member.summary:
Managed instance of the 16 bit LANGID type.
A language identifier is a standard international numeric abbreviation for the language in a country or geographical region. Each language has a unique language identifier (data type LANGID), a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a sublanguage identifier.

member.summary: Primary language identifier.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.LANGID.#ctor(System.UInt16)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the struct.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.LANGID.#ctor(System.UInt16,System.Byte)
member.summary: Creates a language identifier from a primary language identifier and a sublanguage identifier. See MAKELANGID.
member.param: Primary language identifier. This identifier can be a predefined value or a value for a user-defined primary language. For a user-defined language, the identifier is a value in the range 0x0200 to 0x03FF. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.

Sublanguage identifier. This parameter can be a predefined sublanguage identifier or a user-defined sublanguage. For a user-defined sublanguage, the identifier is a value in the range 0x20 to 0x3F. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.LANGID.#ctor(Vanara.PInvoke.LANGID.LANG,Vanara.PInvoke.LANGID.SUBLANG)
member.summary: Creates a language identifier from a primary language identifier and a sublanguage identifier. See MAKELANGID.
member.param: Primary language identifier. This identifier can be a predefined value or a value for a user-defined primary language. For a user-defined language, the identifier is a value in the range 0x0200 to 0x03FF. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.

Sublanguage identifier. This parameter can be a predefined sublanguage identifier or a user-defined sublanguage. For a user-defined sublanguage, the identifier is a value in the range 0x20 to 0x3F. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.CompareTo(Vanara.PInvoke.LCID)
member.summary: Compares the current object with another object of the same type.
member.param: An object to compare with this object.
member.returns: A value that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has the following meanings: Value Meaning Less than zero This object is less than the parameter.Zero This object is equal to . Greater than zero This object is greater than .

member.name: M:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.CompareTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares the current instance with another object of the same type and returns an integer that indicates whether the current instance precedes, follows, or occurs in the same position in the sort order as the other object.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns: A value that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has these meanings: Value Meaning Less than zero This instance precedes in the sort order. Zero This instance occurs in the same position in the sort order as . Greater than zero This instance follows in the sort order.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_SYSTEM_DEFAULT
member.summary: The default locale for the operating system. The value of this constant is 0x0800.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_USER_DEFAULT
member.summary: The default locale for the user or process. The value of this constant is 0x0400.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_CUSTOM_DEFAULT
member.summary: Windows Vista and later: The default custom locale. When an NLS function must return a locale identifier for a supplemental locale for the current user, the function returns this value instead of LOCALE_USER_DEFAULT. The value of LOCALE_CUSTOM_DEFAULT is 0x0C00.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_CUSTOM_UNSPECIFIED
member.summary: Windows Vista and later: An unspecified custom locale, used to identify all supplemental locales except the locale for the current user. Supplemental locales cannot be distinguished from one another by their locale identifiers, but can be distinguished by their locale names. Certain NLS functions can return this constant to indicate that they cannot provide a useful identifier for a particular locale. The value of LOCALE_CUSTOM_UNSPECIFIED is 0x1000.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_CUSTOM_UI_DEFAULT
member.summary: Windows Vista and later: The default custom locale for MUI. The user preferred UI languages and the system preferred UI languages can include at most a single language that is implemented by a Language Interface Pack (LIP) and for which the language identifier corresponds to a supplemental locale. If there is such a language in a list, the constant is used to refer to that language in certain contexts. The value of LOCALE_CUSTOM_UI_DEFAULT is 0x1400.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_NEUTRAL
member.summary: The neutral locale. This constant is generally not used when calling NLS APIs. Instead, use either LOCALE_SYSTEM_DEFAULT or LOCALE_USER_DEFAULT. The value of LOCALE_NEUTRAL is 0x0000.

member.name: P:Vanara.PInvoke.LCID.LOCALE_INVARIANT
member.summary: Windows XP: The locale used for operating system-level functions that require consistent and locale-independent results. For example, the invariant locale is used when an application compares character strings using the CompareString function and expects a consistent result regardless of the user locale. The settings of the invariant locale are similar to those for English (United States) but should not be used to display formatted data. Typically, an application does not use LOCALE_INVARIANT because it expects the results of an action to depend on the rules governing each individual locale. The value of LOCALE_INVARIANT IS 0x007f.

member.name: T:Vanara.PInvoke.OBJECT_TYPE_LIST
member.summary: The OBJECT_TYPE_LIST structure identifies an object type element in a hierarchy of object types. The AccessCheckByType functions use an array of OBJECT_TYPE_LIST structures to define a hierarchy of an object and its subobjects, such as property sets and properties.

member.name: F:Vanara.PInvoke.OBJECT_TYPE_LIST.level
member.summary: Specifies the level of the object type in the hierarchy of an object and its subobjects. Level zero indicates the object itself. Level one indicates a subobject of the object, such as a property set. Level two indicates a subobject of the level one subobject, such as a property. There can be a maximum of five levels numbered zero through four.
